content.description: Low ball/mantle problem that starts on a low sloping shelf, throw up to the arete where it's the most incut, and beached-whale that mantle. Owen cleaned and flashed this after getting really mad.
content.location: Off the trail, uphill just as you get to the wooden bridged section of the trail. If you're facing Topaz it's directly to the left.

content.description: Striking and perfect arete climb. More technical and less burly. Starts on the lowest left corner, technically the rock you stand on is part of the same boulder, but is OFF for this climb. Use stellar footwork to move your way up the arete, and once at the apex throw right, gain the horn and mantle to the right of the peak. Mantling left of the horn is an easier variation.
content.protection: A few pads and a spotter.
content.location: Obvious sharp looking arete that faces the trail. Directly behind a trapezoid shaped rock perched on it's side. At the base of a large tube shaped rock stack.

content.description:
Unique movement for Culp on an overhanging compression arete. Lowball. It's just as fun as it is small.

Start right hand on a low lip of the arete and left hand on an incut flake on the overhanging face (solid near the top). Either bump to a better lip up the arete, or make a bigger move directly to a large flake on the overhanging face. Hit the top and rock over left/mantle.

The name is actually ironic as I had trouble figuring out this problem. I had some foothold breakage and the top has a tricky tension to it. Also, the boulder looks a bit like a literal piece of cake.

Piece of Cake
content.location: You have to go under or around the problem to best access Owen's Rage + Topaz. It's the boulder directly downhill a few yards.
